pros:
Starbucks is very big on creating an image of welcoming and belonging and they do a good job of fostering that attitude. It's a very diverse company that lives up to its mission and goals. Plus, if you work hard as a barista and you're good at your job, there's multiple career opportunities like shift supervisor, assistant store manager, and store manager.

The bottom line:
Great benefits package
Frequent raises
Owning company stock
cons:
Upper management isn't very responsive to baristas or shift managers. If you have any kind of issue with your work life or your manager, whatever it may be, odds are it will be ignored.

The bottom line:
Overworked, underpaid
No work-life balance
No consistent schedule or consistent days off
High stress

cons: Mismanaged like crazy. Many projects don't really move and end in disarray. Teams are hesitant to work together, and communication is poor. There are ways to get around this, but the lack of good leaders creates an atmosphere where low performing individuals can coast by for years.

pros: Learning to up-sell, Deal with multi-tasking in high stress environment. You'll meet some supportive team-members that will become your friends outside of work. If you play your cards right you can basically work anywhere in the U.S. This company has great pay for minimum wage, competitive hours, corporate stock, college tuition paid for, hotel and flight deals, mileage compensation, great place for upward development.
cons:
Clientele can be very very verbally abusive, you need a thick skin to work here. If you are a barista you basically have no power to defend yourself, even a less-than-pleasant tone in retort to a customer who may have cursed at you, etc can get you a write-up depending on who your manager is. All the power for defense against some of the most blatant harassing behavior is bestowed to your shift, store-manager, or the District Manager. If the "LATTE" model fails, know when to step back and let your manager take over. 

Also depending on the store your hours may be cut in times of slow periods, so make sure to go work for a store in a busy mall or shopping center if you want hours.

Since this company mainly employs high school students, and college students, the workplace drama can get intense. Again, just have a thicker skin because most of the baristas you'll encounter will be good and supportive people.

review_title: Pretty hectic but fun work environment.
pros: Free coffee is great. A lot of the best people (objective human beings) I've met have been working at Starbucks. You can build a special kind of bond with regular customers and having a really good interaction lights up your day. They will pay for your college at ASU and you get very good benefits at a low cost.
cons: The pay isnt great. Usually a dollar or two above minimum wage. Shift supervisors a dollar or two more than baristas. It is not a coffee shop, Starbucks is a fast food resteraunt that happens to specialize in coffee. You are pushed to be as fast as possible and it never stops. I still hear the drive thru "ding" in the headsets in my nightmares. Honestly it's a pretty stressful job. Customers and people in general can be the absolute worst and most entitled garbage imaginable.

review_title: A great company that doesn’t always hire the best leaders.
pros:
The health benefits are a big help. There is a huge support community throughout the company that supports each other however there is not much support for you in your store.
With the right leader giving you the opportunities and guiding their team it’s a perfect place to be .....until they move on.
cons: The leaders are not always genuine. They have the this motto to “lead with empathy” but it is just saying “I support you” and not caring for that partner. My manager in particular has a control problem and we hire a lot of young adults that are not very mature. They say there is opportunity for growth however I have given up plenty of opportunities with other companies because I believed this and to just be taken advantage of. They pay can be considered short coming when we are expecting to produce magic and not given the proper tools or even a reliable team.

pros:
When stores are managed well, they’re a blast. There is an immense amount of work, but store morale is usually high which makes it fun.

Many of these well managed stores are very diverse and inclusive. In my 5 years of being a partner, I had only met one other coworker that had an issue with the diversity and uniqueness of other staff members.
cons:
If a store is managed poorly, staff are often not trained properly, work piles on to the few staff that do know how to do the job (transfers) and shifts are never ending with the expectation that you can and will always cover shifts.

Most stores are not well managed. This stems from the unwillingness and lack of opportunity to promote from within. Although there are chances to move up, often when a manager is needed it is more of an immediate need and district managers are forced/prefer external hires. I worked in two districts, and over half of my many managers were external hires.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Starbucks taught me many things. It taught me about customer service, sales, retail, business operations, but more importantly it taught me the power of human connection. I learned more about how to build rapport and relationships with coworkers and customers than I have working any other job. Your home store is like a family, and the other stores in your district are like cousins and every customer can be a friend. Sure, there are some bad apples, but that’s with any job. You work here and you’ll really learn the humanitarian aspect of operating a successful business. Also, if they offer you promotions: TAKE THEM. You’ll be glad you did.
cons: Sometimes the customers or the people you work with can be a little bit terrible to serve/cooperate with, and it can definitely be a high stress job at times. Especially during the morning rush at a high traffic store.

pros: The benefits are unmatched. Take advantage of FREE college at Arizona State University, as much coffee as you can drink while you work and one free meal, free pound of coffee every week, cheap health insurance, free counseling sessions, free Spotify, and other things. It would be a great first job and a fantastic job while you are young and going to school. You make great friends too. A lot of fun to work there as long as you dont take the job too seriously. It truly is what you make it there
cons:
The pay stinks and if you get a horrible manager they can make your time there miserable. You have an option of transferring to any other corporate store, do it quickly if you dont like the manager. Also if you want the job make sure to keep following up, managers get busy and dont always prioritize hiring. (Mistake on their part)

Dont think you can move up to management, it hardly ever happens (speaking from not only my experience but probably a dozen others i was walking the path with and who came before me)
